raw_text:
Dance music not dead says Fatboy
 
 DJ Norman Cook - aka Fatboy Slim - has said that dance music is not dead, but has admitted it is currently going through a "fallow patch".
 
 The commercial failure of the latest albums by Britain's two biggest dance acts - Fatboy Slim's Palookaville and The Prodigy's Always Outnumbered Never Outgunned - has been coupled with the closure of many "superclubs," and the folding of three dance music magazines. Last month the Brit Awards announced they would no longer be awarding a Best Dance Act prize, with the Brits committee announcing that "dance music is no longer where it's happening in music." These developments lead some to suggest that dance was finished as a popular music genre. Cook acknowledged that much change in the dance world in the four years since his last album, Halfway Between The Gutter And The Stars, but he stressed this did not mean the dance scene was permanently over. "Every week when I was making the album, I was reading articles about the demise of dance music - and obviously that affects you somewhat," he told BBC World Service's The Ticket programme. "I personally don't believe it's either dead or going to die, but it's going through a bit of a fallow patch. "So I think, consciously or subconsciously, reading every week that dance music was dead I would think 'right, scrub that track then'."
 
 Although his album sales in the UK are down - Palookaville stayed in the UK top 75 for just three weeks - Cook has achieved recent global success with his beach parties. And event on Brighton sea front in 2002 attracted 250,000, people, while a later one in Rio achieved a crowd of 360,000. The DVD of the Rio set was the biggest seller of that year.
 
 "With a crowd that big, if the weather's nice, the atmosphere before I even go is so good that about halfway through the first record I think 'I've got them'," Cook said. "I'm always really really nervous before the big ones - they had to give me Valium before Rio, because two hours before I was literally just pacing the floor. "For some reason, especially now I've got a reputation for it, the atmosphere and the joie de vivre that's already going on means all I have to do is play 'up' records." He promised more such parties in more locations around the world - despite problems after the Brighton event, which ended in chaos with many revellers finding themselves stranded as transport ground to a halt. One man also died of a heart attack, and a woman fell to her death during the free party. "We're having to widen our horizons from just beaches, because there's landlocked countries that want to get involved," Cook said. "We're doing Rio at the carnival, at the Maracana, and Sao Paolo - our new gig is famous football stadiums."
 
 The DJ admitted, however, that his massive worldwide success had a downside, with intense media interest in his personal life. In particular, he said he had struggled to cope with tabloid intrusion during the temporary break-up of his marriage to Radio One presenter Zoe Ball, after she was linked with DJ Dan Peppe.
 
 "The tabloid thing has been difficult at times," Cook said. "Especially the me-and-Zoe-Gate - it's quite scary." He said that he had been "determined" that what had happened with Ball did not affect the album. "At first I was doing deliberately jolly tunes so that people wouldn't think I was depressed," he explained. "Then I thought, 'that's not right'." And he highlighted a bizarre coincidence - that one song written before they split had turned out to have a great deal more meaning than intended. "I said to Zoe, 'I did this track called My Masochistic Baby Went And Left Me, do you mind if it's on the album?'" he recalled. "She said, 'yeah, it's hilarious, because your masochistic baby did leave you'." Cook also added that he had some ways of coping with the intense paparazzi pressure, which accumulates at the end of the private road he lives on - where Paul McCartney is a neighbour. "It's almost like prisoners rattling the bars with their mugs," Cook explained. "If there's a pap at the end of the road, everyone knocks on each other's doors - Paul comes round, and we warn him, because we don't know who they're after."
llama3.2:1b: DJ Norman Cook - aka Fatboy Slim - says dance music is not dead but currently going through a "fallow patch" due to commercial failure of his albums. The closure of many dance music magazines and superclubs also contribute to this situation. Despite these challenges, he believes the dance scene will continue despite its demise as a popular genre.
llama3.2:3b: DJ Fatboy Slim says dance music is not dead, but it's going through a "fallow patch" due to its decline in popularity and commercial failure. He attributes this to the closure of superclubs and magazines, as well as the demise of the Best Dance Act prize at the Brit Awards. Despite this, Cook has achieved global success with his beach parties, which have attracted large crowds. He plans to expand these events to more locations worldwide and has been able to cope with intense media interest by surrounding himself with supportive neighbors and having a sense of humor about his personal life.
gemma2:2b: Fatboy Slim believes dance music is not dead but is currently experiencing a period of decline. He acknowledges recent album sales are down and that many clubs and magazines have closed, as well as the Brit Awards abandoning a Best Dance Act award. Despite this, he remains optimistic about the future of dance music, particularly through his successful beach parties. These events attract large crowds, and Cook cites the positive atmosphere created by the audience as key to his success. He plans on expanding his party format beyond beaches to various locations worldwide.  He also faces challenges with intense media scrutiny regarding his personal life, including a high-profile breakup with Zoe Ball. Despite this, he has found ways to cope with the pressure from paparazzi and continues producing new music.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Dance music is not dead but in decline due to commercial failure, fold-up dance magazines, reduced popularity among audiences and DJs, and challenges from political pressure.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Dance music is not definitively dead; it has faced commercial issues and club closures but continues to thrive with international parties. DJ Norman Cook (Fatboy Slim) acknowledges a "fallow patch" in the genre but emphasizes its vitality despite past failures, particularly his album sales being down. Despite massive success and worldwide fame, he faces intense media scrutiny, including tabloid intrusion during his marriage break-up.
qwen2.5:3b: DJ Norman Cook, aka Fatboy Slim, counters claims that dance music is dead by stating it is merely going through a "fallow patch". Despite commercial failure of albums by prominent artists like Fatboy Slim and The Prodigy, he emphasizes the scene's resilience. His album sales in the UK have decreased, but he achieved significant global success with beach parties attracting massive crowds. He promises more worldwide events in famous football stadiums after some controversial experiences. Cook acknowledges challenges due to intense media interest following personal issues, such as his marriage breakup and tabloid coverage of it affecting his work.

The album sales in the UK are down, but Cook has achieved recent global success with his beach parties and event on Brighton sea front in 2002 attracted 250,000, people. smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise, preserving key ideas and details. It captures the main points of the text, including:

1. The commercial failure of the latest albums by Britain's two biggest dance acts - Palookaville and The Prodigy - has led to a decline in popularity.
2. The closure of many "superclubs" and the folding of three dance music magazines have contributed to the demise of dance as a popular music genre.
3. Despite these developments, Cook has achieved recent global success with his beach parties, which attract large crowds and generate significant media attention.
4. Cook has also been praised for his ability to cope with intense media scrutiny, including tabloid intrusion and paparazzi pressure.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about DJ Norman Cook and his career in dance music. Let me read through it carefully.

The first sentence mentions that DJ Norman said dance music isn't dead but is currently in a "fallow patch," meaning it's not doing well. The commercial failure of his latest albums and the closure of clubs sound like factors contributing to this. Then he talks about the Brit Awards, where he won, but they are no longer awarding the Best Dance Act prize. He says dance music isn't really where it's supposed to be in music. I should note that.

Next, he mentions his album sales in the UK didn't drop too much because Palookaville stayed in the top 75 for three weeks, which is unusual. His tours at Brighton and Rio were successful with big crowds. He also mentioned some personal issues like managing to get pregnant in a party, which affected his media presence. He tried writing songs before he split with Radio One's Zoe Ball but found it hard.

In the end, DJ Norman talks about how intense media attention can affect his personal life, especially after getting married. He mentions dealing with paparazzi pressure on his street and using his neighbors as a coping mechanism. His style of keeping the music at par or even messing up songs fits with his persona.

I should make sure to include all these points concisely in one summary.
</think>

DJ Norman Cook, aka Fatboy Slim, has stated that dance music is not dead but continues through what he calls a "fallow patch," due to factors like commercial failures and club closures. He acknowledged the change since his last album but emphasized dance isn't truly where it's happening. Despite sales in the UK being up only slightly, he achieved global success with beach parties, which drew large crowds, including 250,000 at Brighton and 360,000 at Rio. He highlighted the positive atmosphere before big shows, mentioning a song that resonated beyond its intended purpose. However, media attention has occasionally impacted his personal life, particularly after his marriage to Radio One's presenter, Zoe Ball, where he navigated intense tabloid pressure and paparazzi concerns on his street.
tinyllama:1.1b: Dancing music, once considered dead and gone, has come back with a vengeance. DJ Norman Cook, known professionally as Fauboy Slim, has said that dance music is not dead, but has acknowledged that there have been changes in the industry due to commercial failures by two of his biggest peers, The Prodigy and Palookaviulle. These developments have led some to suggest that dance has become a passing trend in popular music, but Cook acknowledges that much change occurred during four years since his last album release, Halfway Between the Gutters and the Stars, which prompted him to recognize "every week when I was making music, I was reading articles about the demise of dance music." Despite being affected by tabloid intrusion during his marriage to Radio One presenter Zoë Ball, Cook claims that he has struggled to cope with media scrutiny. He emphasizes having coped with intense paparazzi pressure that accumulates at the end of his private road, as a means of coping.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Fatboy Slim, also known as Norman Cook, has been discussing dance music since the release of his 2002 album "Palookaville." Since then, dance music sales have plummeted and major magazines have discontinued covering it. However, Cook remains optimistic about the future of dance music. He acknowledges that many people associate dance music with an unfashionable past but he insists it is not dead. "I don't think there's a universal agreement on what dance music is or what it means," Cook says. "There's still room for growth and development in the dance genre." In addition to his album releases, Fatboy has been hosting beach parties at his UK residence, where he continues to entertain crowds with his sun-soaked tracks. Despite facing significant challenges due to unresolved issues following the Rio event, Cook is keen to explore new ideas and collaborations in an attempt to keep the dance music genre thriving.
phi:2.7b: DJ Fatboy Slim says that while dance music is going through a "fallow patch," he personally believes it's not dead. He has achieved recent success with his beach parties in Brighton and Rio, which attracted massive crowds. Although the media often intrudes on his personal life, he's coping by focusing on his music.
orca-mini:3b: Dance music is not dead, according to DJ Norman Cook, also known as Fatboy Slim. Although his album sales in the UK are down, he has achieved recent global success with his beach parties and has plans to hold even more parties in more locations around the world. He admitted that his massive worldwide success had a downside, with intense media interest in his personal life, especially after his marriage to Radio One presenter Zoe Ball ended. Cook also revealed that one song he wrote before their split had turned out to have a great deal more meaning than intended.
hermes3:3b: Fatboy Slim says dance music not dead but in fallow patch; denies it's permanently over.

Cook acknowledged these changes but emphasized that he believes dance music is only going through a temporary period of less popularity. He achieved recent global success with his beach parties, attracting large crowds, and plans to expand to more locations around the world. However, intense media interest in his personal life caused some difficulty for him, such as during the temporary break-up of his marriage to Radio One presenter Zoe Ball.
